newsitem.title: USA: US spot Midco gasoline diffs widen late day.
newsitem.headline: US spot Midco gasoline diffs widen late day.

text.p: U.S. spot gasoline prices gained ground late Tuesday on a combination of moderately higher NYMEX futures and firmer diffs in Group Three and Chicago, players said.
Group Three conventional unleaded was offered at 0.20 cents below May futures, a half cent firmer than midday diffs and one cent firmer than late Monday.
And diffs on Chicago material widened 0.25 cent from midday, recouping about half the differential losses seen earlier in the day, players said.
"There's a lot of expectation there will be lower gasoline stocks in the Williams System the second half of April," one trader said, which supported Chicago diffs.

Traders noted API data released late Tuesday showed a 1.2 million barrel draw on U.S. gasoline stocks for the week ending April 4, but predicted the bullish fundamental would be largely offset by ramped up gasoline production.
The API data showed total U.S. gasoline output surging to 7.7 million barrels per day, a 632,000-barrel increase over the prior week.
Meanwhile, traders said partial restoration of Intercontinental Pipe Line crude flow downstream of Superior, Wisconsin, was having little immediate impact on refined product prices.

"We don't have a shortage of crude so we can wipe concerns off our brow," one Midco trader said, noting crude built by one million barrels last week, according to the API data -- with current stocks 9 million barrels above this time last year.

Part of the IPL crude pipeline, which supplies about 1.4 million barrels a day to midwestern U.S. refiners, was shut from late Saturday evening as a number of pumping stations in Minnesota were knocked out by a power outage there.
Refineries in the large states around the Great Lakes account for about 2.3 million barrels a day of crude processing, or about 15 percent of the U.S. total.
IPL said Tuesday it had restarted Lines 2 and 3, which carry crude to Superior from Edmonton, Alberta, but only at sharply reduced flows.
